name: 大腦中的語言：心理語言學入門
description:
This course is designed as an overview of topics pertaining to the relation between language and mind and can be considered to be an introduction to the field of psycholinguistics. It focuses on language as a phenomenon that is internal to human beings’ heads. Rather than analyzing language as a cultural, external object, it is analyzed here as a psychological, internal one. Thus, we’ll be discussing language not as you see them in textbooks but as they’re represented in the mind. Classes will be conducted in English.
Human beings naturally develop a system of knowledge that enables them to use language. In this course we will discuss:
(i)	 How that system of knowledge is organized and what are its main components and properties
(ii)	 How it is used unconsciously in real time in order to produce and comprehend linguistic expressions
(iii)	How it develops in the individual from birth until puberty
(iv)	How its properties are different in the case of second/foreign languages
goals: To introduce the students to the exciting field of language and mind.
To stimulate both creative thought and critical reading.
syllabus:
Week 1     Introduction

Week 2     Sounds (i): how different sounds are produced

Week 3     Sounds (ii): how babies distinguish between different sounds and how they

           learn to produce them

Week 4     Sounds (iii): what is a sound? Some acoustic properties of sounds

Week 5     Sounds (iv): how are sounds perceived? Which properties are important?

Week 6     Sounds (v): occasional speech errors and what we can learn from them

Week 7     MID-TERM EXAM

Week 8     Words (i): different word categories across languages

Week 9     Words (ii): early words in child English and Chinese

Week 10    Words (iii): how words are organized in our head

Week 11    Words (iv): how words are organized in our head

Week 12    Words (v): why do we process words so fast?

Week 13    Sentences (i): how words are put together

Week 14    Sentences (ii): how words are put together

Week 15    Sentences (iii): basic sentences in child English and Chinese

Week 16    Sentences (iv): understanding sentences in real time: how do we do it?

Week 17    Sentences (v): understanding sentences in real time: how do we do it?

Week 18    TAKE-HOME FINAL EXAM DUE

methodologies.note: Classes will be a combination of general lectures and discussions.
Students will be asked to think about one question per class, which will be used to start the discussion.

This is an important section in the class, as psycholinguistics is an experimental discipline. Students will be introduced to different experimental methods that psycholinguists use to study the mental representations involved in language production and comprehension in adult speakers and also language development in infants. Some of these techniques will be demonstrated in class, with students’ participation.

This course definitely requires the use of audiovisual materials in the class; many lectures will include the use of video to show experiment demonstrations, results, and short documentaries on how language is represented in the mind.

grading.note: The midterm exam will cover the first section of the course (sounds) and it will take place a bit earlier than other courses. It is divided in two parts: a section with True/False statements and another section with short exercises.

The final exam will cover the second and third sections of the course (words and sentences) and it will be a take-home exam, in order to give students more time to complete the answers. Its format is similar to the midterm except that it also features a question to be answered with a very short essay of around 200-300 words.
Students are expected to participate in discussions. When a reading is assigned as homework, they will be required to submit a question about it in class.
